She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Liutofaga's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchasing of chemicals, pesticides, vegetable seeds

loans.name: Faalili

texts.en: Faalili A., 37, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the banana and taro business. She sells to the villagers and the public 4 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Faalili's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to improve her business and her husband will help her operate the business.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, pesticides, vegetable seeds

loans.name: Koreti

texts.en: Koreti P., 33, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the banana and taro business. She sells to the villagers and the public 4 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Koreti's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to improve her business and her husband will help her operate the business.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, pesticides, vegetable seeds

loans.name: Mamaioa

texts.en:
Mamaioa N. is 72 years old and married with ten children. She has many years of experience selling bananas and taro. She sells her fruits and vegetables in her village and to the public three days a week.

Mamaioa has benefited from three successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Mamaioa's only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her banana- and taro-selling business by purchasing seeds and pesticides. Her husband will also help her to operate the business.

loans.use: To improve her banana- and taro-selling business by purchasing seeds and pesticides.

loans.name: Taufau

texts.en:
Taufau T. is 35 years old and married with seven children. She has many years of experience selling bananas and taro. She sells her fruits and vegetables in her village and to the public three days a week.

Taufau has benefited from three successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~$145 USD). SPBD loans are Taufau's only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her banana- and taro-selling business by purchasing seeds and pesticides. Her husband will also help her to operate the business.

loans.use: To improve her banana- and taro-selling business by purchasing seeds and pesticides.

loans.name: Legatasi

texts.en:
Legatasi P. is 46 years old and married with five children. She has many years of experience selling bananas and taro. She sells her fruits and vegetables in her village and to the public two days a week.

Legatasi has benefited from two previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Legatasi's only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her banana- and taro-selling business by purchasing seeds and pesticides. Her husband will also help her to operate the business.

loans.use: To improve her banana- and taro-selling business by purchasing seeds and pesticides.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria I., 34, is married with 2 children.  She has many years of experience in the banana and taro business. She sells to the villagers and the public 5 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Maria's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to purchase chemicals, pesticides and vegetable seeds while her husband helped her in operating the business.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, pesticides, vegetable seeds

loans.name: Savalia

texts.en:
Savalia F. is 72 years old and married with eleven children. She has 5 years of experience running a general store. Her shop is open seven days a week to the public and local villagers.

Savalia has benefited from four previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD). SPBD loans are Legatasi's only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to purchase a new freezer for her store, as well as buy sacks of sugar, rice, and salt, and cases of lamp chops and chicken thighs to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer for her general store and to increase her stock of food items to sell.

loans.name: Alofa

texts.en: Alofa S. T., 53, is married with no children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation/fishing business. She sells to the villagers and the public 4 days per week. She has had 3 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).  SPBD loans are Alofa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to improve her business and  husband will help her operate the business.

loans.use: Purchase fishing net, chemicals, pesticides, bush knives

loans.name: Luavalu

texts.en:
Luavalu I. is 31 years old and married with five children. She has three years of experience in the traditional business of selling necklaces, earrings, and fans. She sells to the public four days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~$125 USD).

Luavalu has one previous loan with SPBD (South Pacific Business Development). SPBD loans are Luavalu’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. Luavalu would be happy to apply a second loan to improving her business, and thus allowing her to better meet her kids’ educational needs. She will use the money to help pay for the electric and water bills that contribute to the running of her business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing maching for her business, pay her water and electricity bill, and fund her kids' school fees.

loans.name: Faauluuluga

texts.en:
Faauluuluga E. is 38 years old and married with four children. She has three years of experience selling chips. She sells to the public three days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 Tala (~$41 USD).

This is Faauluuluga’s first loan with SPBD (South Pacific Business Development), and she is eager to improve her business operation so that she is in better financial standing to support her family. She plans to use the money to buy a stove, frying pan, and 20 liters of oil for her chip-selling business. SPBD loans are her only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan.

loans.use: To purchase a stove, frying pan, and 20 liters of oil for her chip selling business.

loans.name: Sefulu

texts.en:
Sefulu T. is 37 years old and married with five children. She has many years of experience in vegetable gardening. She sells her produce to local villagers and the public three days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD).

Sefulu has one previous loan with SPBD (South Pacific Business Development). SPBD loans are Sefulu’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her vegetable-selling business by purchasing seeds and pesticides. Her husband will also help her to operate the business.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides and seeds for her vegetable business.

loans.name: Mele

texts.en:
Mele T. is 59 years old and married with seven children. She has four years of experience selling desserts and cakes. She sells to local villagers and the public seven days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD).

Mele has two previous loans with SPBD (South Pacific Business Development), and she is eager to further improve her business operation by purchasing plastic cups, sugar, and Kool Aid. SPBD loans are her only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan.

loans.use: To purchase plastic cups, sugar, and Kool Aid.

loans.name: Lise

texts.en:
Lise F. is 22 years old and married with one child. She has many years of experience selling bananas and taro. She sells her fruits and vegetables in her village and to the public two days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD).

Lise has benefited from one previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loan. SPBD loans are Lise’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her banana- and taro-selling business by purchasing pesticides and farming tools. Her husband will also help her to operate the business.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides and farming tools.

loans.name: Fetu

texts.en:
Fetu L. is 25 years old and married with three children. She has four years of experience selling homemade bricks. She sells her bricks in her village and to the public five days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD).

Fetu has benefited from two previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. SPBD loans are Fetu’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her brick business by purchasing cement, sand, a wheel barrow, and shovels. Her husband will also help her to operate the business.

loans.use: To purchase cement, sand, a wheel barrow, and shovels for her brick business.

loans.name: Ata

texts.en:
Ata T. is 25 years old and married with seven children. She has four years of experience selling cream buns. She sells her treats at a food stall in the village six days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~$83 USD).

Ata has benefited from four previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. SPBD loans are Ata’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her business by purchasing flour, sugar, and coconuts. She is a very young mother aiming to be successful in the future.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, and coconuts for her cream bun business.

loans.name: Matagiaila

texts.en:
Matagiala E. is 42 years old and married with seven children. She has two years of experience selling 'elei,' traditional Samoan printed cloth. She sells her clothing in her village and to the public six days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~$62 USD).

Matagiala has benefited from one previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loan. SPBD loans are Matagiala’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her clothing business by purchasing fabric, materials, needles, paints, and brushes. She is a very young mother aiming to be successful in the future.

loans.use: To purchase fabric, materials, needles, paints, and brushes to create traditional Samoan printed clothing.

loans.name: Iaeli

texts.en:
Iaeli L. is 62 years old and married with eight children. She has two years of experience selling 'elei,' traditional Samoan printed cloth. She sells her clothing in her village and to the public six days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~$83 USD).

Iaeli has benefited from one previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loan. SPBD loans are Iaeli's only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her clothing business by purchasing fabric, materials, needles, paints, and brushes.

loans.use: To purchase fabric, materials, needles, paints, and brushes to create 'elei', traditional Somoan print clothing.

loans.name: Ruth Veronica

texts.es:
Ruth tiene 26 años. Ella tiene un salón de belleza, además de eso, se dedica a la venta de productos cosméticos. Anteriormente ella trabajaba en diversas peluquerías, sin embargo, ella quería tener un negocio propio, fue así que logro abrir su salón de belleza.
El último crédito que ella recibió lo empleo en comprar productos cosméticos para su salón de belleza.
Ahora ella cuenta que necesita renovar los muebles y herramientas que ella utiliza para trabajar, y para eso necesita un pequeño capital que haga posible cumplir sus proyectos.
texts.en:
Ruth is 26 years old. She runs a beauty salon and she also sells cosmetics. Prior to these businesses she used to work in hair styling salons but she always dreamed of having her own business. That's how she managed to open her own beauty salon.

The last loan she received she used to purchase cosmetics for her beauty salon. She now indicates that she needs to renovate her furniture and she needs new tools that she uses for work. For this reason she requires a small capital fund that will grant her the ability to accomplish her goals.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To renovate furniture and purchase new tools for her beauty salon.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
Felicitas tiene 58 años. Desde hace varios años ella se dedica a la venta de golosinas. Antes sólo tenía un pequeño puesto ambulante de golosinas. Sin embargo, con un poco de esfuerzo ella logró abrir una tienda en su casa, para si poder pasar más tiempo con su familia.
Ella cuenta que tiene un hijo, que actualmente está en el colegio, y ella trabaja duro para que su hijo siga con sus estudios.
El último crédito que ella recibió lo utilizo en surtir su tienda de golosinas, aunque por otros gastos que ella tuvo no le alcanzo para comprar lo que tenía proyectado. 
Ahora ella cuenta que necesita otro crédito para seguir adelante con su negocio.
texts.en:
Felicitas is 58-years-old. She has sold candy for several years. She used to have only a small cart with which she sold candy as a street vendor. However, with a little effort, she managed to open a store in her house to be able to spend more time with her family. She has one son, who is currently in high school. She works hard so he can continue with his studies. She used the last loan she received to supply her candy store, although because of other costs she wasn't able to buy all that she had planned. Today she tells us that she needs another loan to continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by N Aviva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to supply her store with candy

loans.name: María Luz

texts.es:
María tiene 60 años. Ella tiene un depósito de cerveza en su casa desde hace 2 años. Además, por las noches, ella sale a vender comida en un puesto ambulante. Anteriormente, ella administraba un taller de cerrajería, sin embargo, por los bajos ingresos que le producía tuvo que cerrarlo. 
El último crédito que ella recibió le ayudo a comprar las bebidas que ella vende. 
Sin embargo, ella cuenta que ahora necesita un nuevo crédito para comprar una congeladora, ya que para el negocio que ella tiene, es indispensable.
texts.en:
Maria is 60 years old. She has been selling beer from her house for the last two years and she also sells food in the evenings, door to door. Prior to this she use to manage a locksmith shop but the income from this business was just too small and she had to close it up.

The previous loan she received helped her purchase the drinks that she now sells. But she still requires another loan to purchase a fridge, a very important appliance for her business.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a fridge for her business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
Guadalupe tiene 48 años. Ella tiene una tienda de productos comestibles, además por las noches tiene un puesto ambulante de comida, que le genera ingresos extras. Su esposo es taxista y esta fuera de casa todo el día. Guadalupe tiene un hijo que asiste al colegio y cuenta que es buen estudiante.
El último crédito que Guadalupe recibió lo empleo en el mantenimiento del auto de su esposo y en su negocio ambulante de comida.
Sin embargo ella necesita otro crédito que le permita comprar productos para surtir su tienda.
texts.en:
Guadalupe is a 48-year-old woman who has a small grocery store. Additionally, she sells fast food on a cart every night, which generates extra income for her. Her husband is a taxi cab driver, so he is away from home all day long. Guadalupe has one son who still attends school. She tells us that he is a good student. The last loan that Guadalupe obtained was used for maintenance on her husband’s cab and for her street food business. However, she now needs another loan that with allow her to purchase products to restock her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock grocery store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Manuel tiene 56 años. Desde de hace varios años se dedica a la venta de ropa en general y estampados publicitarios en ropa deportiva e industrial.
Actualmente no cuenta con un taller propio donde trabajar, por lo que trabaja en un pequeño espacio de su vivienda. 
El crédito que anteriormente recibió Manuel le sirvió para comprar materiales como telas y tintes de estampado. Ahora el necesita otro crédito, ya que planea poner un pequeño taller que le permita un trabajo más apropiado.
texts.en:
Manuel is 56 years old. Since several years ago, he has sold clothing and imprints advertisements on sports and industrial clothing. At the moment, he does not have his own workshop, so he works in a small space in his home. Manuel used the loan that he previously received to purchase material such as fabric and printing dye. Now he needs another loan, which he plans to put into a small workshop that will be more suitable for his work.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Tatman Montgomery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To open a workshop for producing clothing and imprinting advertisements

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eveliza

texts.es:
Eveliza tiene 29 años. Ella se dedica al alquiler de llamadas telefónicas de celulares, desde hace un año, además por las noches ella tiene un puesto de comida ambulante. Anteriormente Eveliza trabajaba en un taller de costura, sin embargo no pudo seguir trabajando, ya que tuvo una hija y tenía que cuidarla.
El último crédito que ella recibió, lo empleo en comprar equipos celulares para su negocio. Ahora ella necesita otro crédito para comprar una congeladora, ya que piensa vender helados y bebidas gaseosas.
texts.en:
Eveliza is 29 years old. For the past year, she has worked renting out cell phones for making phone calls. She also works as a food vendor at night. She used to work in a seamstress' shop, but then her daughter was born, so she had to quit so that she could take care of the baby. The last loan Evelita took out was used to buy cell phones for her business. She plans to use this loan to buy a freezer, because she would like to start selling ice cream and sodas.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a freezer to sell ice cream and sodas

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth tiene 38 años. Ella tiene un puesto ambulante ubicado cerca del mercado de su comunidad, donde se dedica a la venta de frutas, desde hace tres años. Adicionalmente, vende comida por las noches en un puesto ambulante. Ella tiene tres hijos menores, que actualmente estudian, por lo que ella trabaja duro para cubrir los gastos del colegio.
El último crédito que Elizabeth recibió le ayudo a comprar un carrito sanguchero para trabajar por las noches. Sin embargo, ella cuenta que piensa comprar un congelador para vender helados y bebidas gaseosas, por lo que necesita un crédito para financiar su proyecto.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is 38 years old. She has a mobile stand on the street near her community’s market, where she has sold fruit for three years. Additionally, she sells food at night from her stand. She has there small children who are in school, and she works hard to cover their school expenses. The last loan Elizabeth received help her buy a small cart so she could work in the evenings. Nevertheless, she tells us she is thinking of buying a refrigerator freezer to sell ice cream and soda pop, so she needs a loan to finance her project.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a refrigerator freezer to sell ice cream and soda pop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Modesta

texts.es:
Modesta tiene 44 años. Ella tiene un negocio en casa, una pensión donde brinda desayunos y cenas. Por las tardes ella ayuda en el comedor popular de su comunidad, adicionalmente, los domingos ella sale a vender mazamorra morada.
El último crédito que ella recibió, lo empleo en la reparación de su congelador que utiliza en su negocio de comida.
Ella cuenta que hace poco le  robaron la olla donde preparaba su mazamorra morada, y como es una olla grande y costosa, necesita un crédito para comprar otra. Asimismo ella necesita también algo de dinero para invertir en su negocio de comida.
texts.en:
Modesta is 44 years old. She has a business from her house; a guesthouse where she provides breakfast and dinner. In the afternoons she helps in a popular eatery in her community. Additionally, on Sundays she goes out to sell mazamorra morada (a sweet pudding made from constarch, sugar, and honey).

She used the last loan that she received to repair her freezer, which she uses in her food business. She reports that someone recently stole the pot that she uses to make her mazamorra morada and, since it is a large and expensive pot, she needs a loan to buy another. Additionally, she needs some money to invest in her food business.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Tatman Montgomery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a large pot for her mazamorra morada (local corn pudding) business and to invest in her food business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: María Rosa

texts.es:
María tiene 53 años. Ella se dedica desde hace cinco años a la venta de joyería. Ella visita a sus vecinas de su localidad para ofrecer sus productos.
María cuenta que es viuda, y aunque cuenta con la pensión de su fallecido esposo, le es insuficiente para cubrir sus gastos y los de su hijo que esta por terminar el colegio y desea ir a la universidad. Es por eso que María tiene que dedicarse a la joyería para generar ingresos extras.
El último crédito que María recibió le ayudo a comprar las joyas que ella vende, asimismo ella necesita otro crédito, ya que desea seguir con su negocio de joyería y hacerlo más productivo.
texts.en:
María is 53 years old. She has worked for the past five years selling jewelry. She visits her neighbors in her area in order to offer her products. María is a widow, and although she has a pension from her departed husband, it is insufficient to cover her expenses and those of her son, who is finishing high school and wants to go to university. This is the reason that María has to work selling jewelry in order to get extra income. The last credit that María received helped her to buy the jewels that she sells. She needs another loan for the same reason. She wants to continue with her jewelry business and to make it more productive.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products for María's jewelry business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Carmen Patricia

texts.es:
Carmen tiene 38 años. Ella se dedica a la costurería desde hace varios años, adicionalmente vende productos de belleza. 
Carmen tiene 2 hijos pequeños que cuidar, por lo que su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su vivienda.
El último crédito que recibió lo empleo en acondicionar un espacio en su vivienda para trabajar.
Sin embargo ella cuenta que su máquina de coser está  averiada, por lo que necesita un crédito para repararla.
texts.en:
Carmen is 38 years old. She has worked as a seamstress for a few years, and also sells beauty products. Carmen has two small children to care for, and because of this her business is located in her home. She used the last loan she received to air condition her work space at home. Nonetheless, right now her sewing machine is broken, and she needs a loan to repair it.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair her sewing machine

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria tiene 40 años. Desde hace seis años se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza. Su esposo es obrero, por lo que esta fuera de casa todo el día, además Victoria tiene dos hijos en edad escolar. 
Victoria, para mantener su negocio necesariamente tiene que vender sus productos a crédito, y eso le genera un vació de capital.
El último crédito que recibió lo invirtió en la compra de productos de belleza. 
Sin embargo, ella cuenta que necesita un capital para amortiguar el dinero de los productos que vende a crédito.
texts.en:
Victoria is 40 years old. For the past 6 years she has worked selling beauty products. Her husband is a laborer, and because of this is out of the house all day. Also, Victoria has two school-aged children. In order to maintain her business, Victoria has to sell her products on credit, and this generates a cash flow gap. The last loan that she received was invested in the purchase of beauty products. She realizes that she needs capital to invest the money in the products that she sells on credit.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cash for the products Victoria sells on credit

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Duch Sass's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank [a solidarity group], which consists of eight members, is located in Kandal Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Duch S. is the village bank president, who has been selected by its members. She is a farmer and Khmer noodle seller. Because the second business is going well, she wants to expand it; so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more Khmer noodles to re-sell to her customers. She hopes to increase her income and improve her standard of living with this new loan. Mrs. Duch S. is a 53-year-old widow with a child who is attending the local school.

All the members in this village bank loan have end-of-term loans, and they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK (Kiva’s Field Partner)’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more Khmer noodles to re-sell to customers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Much Non's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Much N. is the leader of this group of four. They now live in O'Rum Chek Village in the Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Much N. is a basket maker who can earn a small income to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Bu Sao, owns a plot of land where he cultivates rice to earn a living. Unfortunately, Mr. Bu Sao now faces a small problem because his rice field is infertile, which affects his crop. To solve this problem, his wife decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizers to enrich the field in order to make the crop more productive. Mrs. Much N. is 45 years old and the mother three children. One of the children is a farmer, while the others are attending the local school. 

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans, and they are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK (Kiva’s Field Partner) has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for the field in order to make the crop more productive

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Nom Phy's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank [solidarity group] consists of sixteen people and is located in Sre Sa Village in the Kampong Chhnang Province. The group members all have different uses for their loans. Mrs. Nom P. is the village bank president and is a farmer. On her plantation, she can make a small income to support her household. Her husband, Mr. Vong Vin, is a firewood seller who can earn less than $2 to meet the family expenses. Mrs. Nom P. is 51 years old and the mother of four children. Two of the children are employed in a garment factory, while another one is a farmer. The youngest child is attending the local school. Although Mrs. Nom P. and the family members have different businesses, they still cannot effort to build a new house for themselves. In order to meet this need and live in better conditions, Mrs. Nom P. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings and to build a new house.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK (Kiva’s Field Partner) has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To help build a new house in order to live in better conditions

loans.name: Mrs. Khek Chea's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people in Sre Sa Village in Kampong Chhnang Province make up this village bank loan. They each plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Khek C. is the village bank president and is a farmer who owns a hectare to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Vong Sean, is a construction worker and firewood seller. Because the second business is going well, he wants to expand it; so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more firewood to re-sell to the customers. Mrs. Khek C. is 59 years old and the mother of five children. Two of the children are construction workers, while another is a farmer. The remaining two are attending the local school.

Mr. Nuon Y.’s wife came to take out the loan for her husband, so she is presented in the picture.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK (Kiva’s Field Partner) has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more firewood to re-sell to customers

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy P. is 57 years old and married with six children. She has many years of experience in the grocery business. She sells her groceries in her village and to the public six days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD).

Daisy has benefited from five previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. SPBD loans are Daisy’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her business and to help financially support her family. Her husband also helps out with her grocery sales.

loans.use: To purchase items to improve her grocery sales and business status, and to help financially support her family.

loans.name: Toeaso

texts.en:
Toeaso R. is 37 years old and married with three children. She has many years of experience selling pancakes, pork pies, ice cakes (sweet frozen treats) and other food items. She sells her products in her village and to the public six days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 650 Tala (~$270 USD).

Toeaso has benefited from three previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. SPBD loans are Toeaso’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her foodstall and to help financially support her family. Her husband also helps out with her business.

loans.use: To improve her business status and to help financially support her family.

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Samean's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom S. is the president of this village bank [solidarity group] of twelve people in Choeung Khnar Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is currently in the business of selling vegetables. Because this business is going well, she wants to expand it; so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to re-sell to her customers. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this new loan. Her husband, Mr. Seik Phally, owns a plot of land where he can cultivate rice to earn a living. Mrs. Mom S. is 33 years old and the mother of a 3-year-old child, who is too young to work or study.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans, and they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK [Kiva’s Field Partner] has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more vegetable in order to re-sell to her customers.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda P. is 30 years old and married with four children. She has many years of experience selling groceries. She has a general store in her village, and she sells to the public six days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (~$291 USD).

Linda has benefited from two previous successful SPBD (South Pacific Business Development) loans. SPBD loans are Linda’s only access to capital, because she is not able to qualify for a traditional bank loan. She will use her loan to improve her business status and also to help pay for her kids' school fees. She desires to increase sales so that she may better financially support her family. Her husband also helps out with her business.

loans.use: To buy items to improve her business status and help financially support her family and pay for her kids' school fees.

loans.name: Losa

texts.en: Losa S. is 32 years old and married with two children.  She has many years of experience working on taro, yam, and banana plantations, where she harvests fruit to sell to people in her village.  Losa earns just over $200 per week and often works with her children.  Microfinance is Losa's only access to capital because traditional banks are reluctant to lend to her, although she has already successfully repaid her first loan.  Losa is now requesting a loan of $400 to improve her family's fruit business and also to improve her family's home.

loans.use: To improve business practices and also to improve her home.

loans.name: Emi

texts.en: Emi S. is 49 years old and married with ten children.  She has five years of experience working with her husband in the fabric printing business, and for many years has sold printed fabrics to people in her village.  Emi earns about $125 per week and is only able to access capital through microfinance institutions because traditional banks are reluctant to lend to her.  Emi is now requesting a loan of $300 to help her buy new ink and fabric for her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric, carved design, paint and brushes.

loans.name: Mrs. Chhuon Bun Chhoeurn's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen members form this village bank [solidarity group] in Choeung Khnar Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Chhuon B. C. is the village bank president and owns a small restaurant where she can sell Chinese noodle and rice soup to the villagers and passersby. Because this business is going well, she wants to expand it; so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients in order to cook the delicious food for her customers. Her husband, Mr. Seng Sophally, helps her when he has free time from his motorbike taxi business. Mrs. Chhuon B. C. is 52 years old and the mother of four children. Two of the children assist with their mother’s business, while the remaining two are attending the local school.

Mr. Phan S. did not come to take out his loan, but his wife did and is presented in the photo.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK [Kiva’s Field Partner] has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to cook delicious food for her customers

loans.name: Mataniu

texts.en: Mataniu L. is 43 years old and has several children.  She has kept a vegetable garden for two years, and regularly sells the produce to people in her village.  Having been turned down by traditional banks on several occasions, Mataniu realized microfinance was her only access to capital, and has already successfully repaid her first loan.  Mataniu now wants to expand her business, which she manages with her husband, and is therefore requesting a loan of $475 so that she can purchase basic gardening tools and seeds.

loans.use: To purchase water hose, rake, cabbage seeds and other vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Loisi

texts.en: Loisi Soo is 36 years old and married with four children.  She has worked with her husband in the taro and banana business for five years, and sells the fruit to people in her village on a regular basis.  Loisi earns about $160 per week, and has already successfully paid off previous microfinance loans, which are her only access to capital.  Loisi is now requesting a loan of $850, which will be used to buy more sophisticated equipment for her banana business.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides, sprayers, and other gardening equipment

loans.name: Afolau

texts.en: Afolau V. is 59 years old and married with seven children.  She has worked in the plantation business for many years with her husband, and often sells her produce to people in her village.  Afolau earns about $185 per week, and has successfully repaid previous loans.  Because microfinance is her only access to capital, Afolau is now requesting a loan of $500, which will be used to purchase herbicides and other equipment to further increase her agricultural productivity.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, pesticides,back sprayer etc

loans.name: Mamapo

texts.en: Mamapo F. is 42 years old and married with five children.  She has worked for two years producing chips and selling them to people in her village.  Mamapo earns about $145 per week, and has successfully repaid a previous loan. Microfinance is her only access to capital because traditional banks are reluctant to lend to small businesses like hers.  Therefore, Mamapo is requesting a loan of $500 to help her purchase ingredients for chips and other materials.

loans.use: To purchase plastic papers, bananas, salt, vegetable oil, and other ingredients.

loans.name: Mine

texts.en: Mine A. is 29 years old and married with one child.  She has worked for two years in the barbecue business, where she cooks and sells food with her husband to people in her village. Mine earns about $165 per week, and has successfully repaid two loans.  Because microfinance is her only access to capital, Mine is now requesting a loan of $475 to purchase equipment that will her improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase barbecue equipment.

loans.name: Mrs. Pol Sarum's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank [solidarity group] consists of twenty people and is located in Krang Leav Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Pol S. is the village bank president, who has been selected by its members. She is a firewood seller who can make a small income to support her household. Aside from this business, she is a farmer. Currently she cannot cultivate her rice plantation because she does not have enough animals to plow the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow to help the old one plow her field. Her husband, Mr. Ung Phang, is a construction worker who can earn less income to meet the family expenses. Mrs. Pol S. is 42 years old and the mother of two children, who are both attending the local school. All the members are presented in the picture, but some of them are being blocked.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans, and they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK [Kiva’s Field Partner] has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy one more cow to help the old one plow her field

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia S. is 35 years old and married with three children.  She has worked in the barbecue business with her husband for over a year, where she cooks and sells food to people in her village.  She earns about $166 per week, and has repaid two previous loans, which she found to be very helpful in expanding her business.  Because microfinance is her only access to capital, Telesia is now requesting a loan of $500 to purchase equipment that will help her expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to help barbecue cooking.

loans.name: Matalena

texts.en: Matalena P. is 53 years old and married with seven children.  Having worked with her husband for three years in the sewing business, where she produces and sells fabrics to people in her village, she now earns about $125 per week.  Because traditional banks are reluctant to lend to her, Matalena is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more sophisticated equipment for sewing.

loans.use: Purchase to buy for the equipments used in her business

loans.name: Hana

texts.en: Hana M. is 42 years old and married with five children.  She has three years of experience working with her husband in a vegetable garden.  They sell the produce from their garden to people in her village and as a result she earns about $166 per week.  Hana has successfully repaid two loans, and has found that microfinance is her only access to capital because traditional banks are reluctant to lend to small businesses.  She is now requesting a loan of $500 to purchase equipment for gardening.

loans.use: Purchase to buy for the equipments used in her business

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en: Faafetai O. is 52 years old and married with four children.  She has worked in her vegetable garden and sold the vegetables to people in her village for three years, and earns about $200 per week.  Because microfinance is Faafetai's only access to capital, she has taken out and successfully repaid four previous loans.  In order to further expand her business, however, Faafetai is now requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase gardening tools and seeds.

loans.use: To purchase gardening tools and seeds.

loans.name: Temurhon

texts.ru: Дадахонов Темурхон молодой человек в возросте 23 года,женат . Темур уже 4 года как имеет свой бизнес, в открытии которого ему помог его отец.Сначало Темур ездил за товаром, и просто помогал отцу , но достигнув совершенолетия отец ему доверил всё дело. И уже его бизнес достиг больших успехов. В его магазине ассортимент состоит из продуктов питания и дессертных сладостей. Т.к. в дальнейшем сезонный период то Темур решил взять кредит для увеличения ассортимента продуктов питания.
texts.en:
Temurhon D. is a young man of 23, and married. His father helped him to start his shop four years ago. In the beginning Temur simply assisted his father by procuring the merchandise, but once he was of age his father entrusted him with the entire business. It has proven to be quite successful, and the store carries a range of food products and sweets. Temur has decided to take out a loan in order to further expand the variety of foods.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Food products

loans.name: Muhayo

texts.ru: Наимова Мухаё женщина в возросте 30 лет имеет 2 детей , работает учительницей начальных классов. Из-за того что заработная плата учителей очень низкая,Мухаё имеет свой маленький магазинчик, где она продаёт хозяйственные товары.И имеет дополнительный доход.Узнав от подруг что они кредитуются в Микроинвесте , она решила взять кредит на увеличение ассортимента товаров.
texts.en:
Muhayo N. is a woman of 30, who has two children. She works as a primary school teacher. To augment the low salary she earns as a teacher, Muhayo has a small shop where she sells household products. Having learned that some of her friends had loans from MicroInvest, she decided to take out a loan to expand the variety of products she carries.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Retail Sale of Household Products

loans.name: Mrs. Chea Hob's Village Loan Group

texts.en:
This Village Bank [solidarity group] consists of 16 people located in Sre S. Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Chea H. is the village bank president, and is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Kem Phang, is a cow breeder and firewood seller. As the second business is going well, he wants to expand it; so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more firewood to re-sell the customers. Mrs. Chea H. hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions. She is 36 years old and the mother of three children. Two of them are attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

Mrs. Leng N. and Mrs. Sam S. did not come to receive their loans, but their husbands did and so are presented in the picture.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Nine members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK [Kiva’s Field Partner] has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more firewood to re-sell to the customers

loans.name: Salomat

texts.ru: Валиева Саломат торгует с сестрой на рынке, недавно она вышла  замужем. Когда она с сестрой была еще  маленькой,  ее мать торговала детской одеждой, они выходил, и помогали ей на рынке. Научились торговать, и мать доверяла ей товар. Сейчас Саломат торгует женской одеждой в торговле помогает ее сестра Сураё, так как  вскоре  Саломат будет матерью  и она не сможет выходить  на работу. У них  сейчас сезон продажи школьной одежды и торговля по их словам идет очень хорошо.
texts.en:
Salomat V. is in business with her sister at the market. When she and her sister were young they helped their mother sell children’s clothing in the marketplace. Once she learned the business her mother entrusted her with goods. Now Salomat trades in women’s clothing with her sister’s assistance. She recently married and will soon be a mother and not able to go out to work. It is now time to sell school uniforms, and in their opinion the business is doing very well.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Mr. Uong Teng's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank [solidarity group] consists of 15 people and is located in Sre Sa Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mr. Uong T. is the village bank president. He owns a small kiln where he can make coal to sell for an income. His wife, Mrs. Doeuk Hon, has a plot of land to cultivate rice. Besides this, she is a breeder who raises three cows. Mr. Uong T. is 58 years old and the father of six children, who are all attending the local school. Although Mr. Uong T. and his wife both have businesses, they still cannot effort to build a new house for their household. In order to meet this need, Mr. Uong T. decided to ask for a loan to add to his savings to build a house for his family.

Mr. Doeurk C. did not come to take out a loan, but his wife did and is shown in the picture instead of her husband.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Six members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK [Kiva’s Field Partner] has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To help build a house for his family

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en:
Gulsara G. has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2006. She is the executive of her business, and she is a reliable client who has not any problems repaying her prior loans.

Gulsara lives in the Nau region of Tajikistan. She is married, and she has 5 children. She is engaged in the business of trading towels, headscarves for women, and shoes. She purchases the goods herself so she has the opportunity to trade such goods for higher prices in order to generate profits for her business. Notably, she has many repeat customers and customers who buy goods in bulk.

Now, Gulsara is seeking, via Kiva, a business development loan in the amount of 4,000 STJ ($1,175) to be repaid in 4 months to import new seasonal goods and to thereby diversify her product offerings.

loans.use: To diversify her product line by importing additional seasonal goods

loans.name: Nihoyat

texts.en:
Nihoyat D., who was born in the Spitamen region of Tajikistan, is married and has 3 children. She is a schoolteacher, but her livestock business provides the general income needed to support her family. In fact, Nihoyat has been involved in the livestock business for her entire life as she used to help her mother take care of their animals.

Now, she is engaged in the business of purchasing and selling livestock. Fortunately, she has good business skills that she utilizes on a daily basis. Nihoyat is applying for a business development loan in the amount of 2,600 STJ ($775) for 5 months through Kiva to expand and improve her livestock business by purchasing additional livestock.

loans.use: To expand and improve her livestock business
